(1) Where it is alleged that two or more persons greet (ety are jointly or severally, or jointly and severally, liable tn dalit. ae ‘ in delict to any other person (hereinafter referred to a the  plaintafl ”) Zor tho same damage, such persons (hereinafter referred to as the ‘‘ joint wrongdoers ”’) may be sued in the same action.
(2) Notice of any action may at any time be given—
{a) by the plaintiff; or
@) by any joint wrongdoer who is sued in that

action: to any other joint wrongdoer who is ot so sued and who may, upon receipt of such notice, intervene as a defendant in that i action. \ (8) The court may, on the application of the plaintiff j or any joint wrongdoer in any action, order that separate trials shall be held, or make such other order on such application as it may consider just and expedient.

( (@) Where a joint wrongdoer is not sued in any action instituted against any other joint wrongdoer and no notice is given to him in terms of paragraph @) of ‘sub-section (2), the plaintiff shall not thereafter sue him, except with the leave of the court on good cattse shown es to why notice was not given as
i aforesaid. i .

. (2) Where no notice, under paragraph (a) or @) of sub-section ®, is given to a joint wrongdoer who is not sued by e plaintiff, no proceedings for a contri- bution shall be instituted against him under sub-section
= (8) or (7) by any other joint wrongdoer, except with the leave of the court on good cause shown as to why notice ‘was not given to him under the said paregrap!
i (8) In any subsequent action against another joint wrongdoer, ony, amount recovered from any Joint
"wrongdoer in a former action shall be deemed to have
‘been spplied towards the payment of the costs awarded in the former action in priority to the liquidation of the damages awarded in that aotion.

@ (@) Where judgment in any action is given against Any joint wenger for the full amount cf the damage soffered by the plaintiff, the said joint wrongdoer may, if the judgment debt has been paid in Full, but subject to the prcvisions of paragraph (b) of sub-section (4), recover from any other joint wrongdoer a contribution in respect of his responsibility for such damage of such an amount as the court may deem ust and equitable having regard to the degree in which
_ that other joint wrongdeer wae at fault in relation to
+ the damage suffered’ by the plaintiff, and to the damages awarded.

(®) The period of prescription in respect of a claim for a contribution shall be twelve months ealoulated from the date of the judgment in respect of which 0 contribution ig claimed or, where an appeal is made against such judgment, from the date of the final . judgment on appeal:
: Provided that if, in the case of any joint wrongdoer, the period of prescription in relation to any action which may be instituted against him by the plaintiff,

: is governed by a law which prescribes a period of lesa than twelve months es the period within which legal proceedings shall be instituted against him or within which notice shall be given that proceedings will be instituted against him, the provisions of such law shail apply matatis mutandis in relation to any action for @ contribution by a joint wrongdoer, the period or periods concerned being calculated from the date of
| the judgment as aforesaid instead of from the date of the original cause of action.

(7) (@) Where judgment in any action is given against one or more jem prongdoers in respect & the damage suffered by the plaintiff and any joint wrong- doer, in pursuance of such judgment,—
@) pays to the plaintiff an amount in respect of his
responsibility for such damage; and
Gi) the amount so paid is in excess of the amoant

(hereinafter referred to as the “‘ amount . apportioned to the first-mentioned joint wrongdoer *’) which the court deems just and equitable, having regard to the degree in which he was at fault in relation to the damage suffered by the plaintiff aud to the full amount of the damages awarded to the plaintiff, such joint wrongdoer may, subject to the provisions of paragraph (@) of, eub-seebion (4), recover from any other joint wrongdoer a contribution in respect of su other wrongdoer's responsibility for such damage of an amount not exceeding so much of the amount which the coure deems just and equitable, heving regard to the degree in which such other joint wrongdoer was at fault in relation to the damage suffered by the plaintiff and to the full amount of the damages awarded to the plaintiff, as has not been paid by such other wrongdoer to the plaintiff or to any other wrongdoer, or so much of the amount paid by the first-mentioned wrongdoer as exceeds the amount apportioned to him, whichever is Jess.
(0) The provisions of paragraphs (6) and (¢) of sub- section (6) shall apply mutatis mutandis to any claim for a contribution under paragraph (a) of this sub- section,
(8) @ Where judgment in any action is given in
, favour of the plaintiff against two or more joint wrongdoers, the court-—
(i) may order that auch joint wrongdoers pay the
‘amount of the damages awarded joiatly and j severally, the one paying and the other being i absolved;
Law Reform (Contributory Negligence ond 5 Joint Wrongdoers) Act, No. 12 of 1968

(ii) may, if it is satisfied that all the joint wrongdoers have been joined in the action, apportion the damages awarded against the said joint wrongdoers in such proportions as the court may deem just and equitable having regard to the degree in which each joint wrongdoer was at fault in relation to the damage suffered by the plaintiff, and give judgment separately against each joint wrongdoer for the amount so apportioned :

Provided that any amount which the plaintifi is unable to recover from any joint wrongdoer under a judgment so given (including any costs incurred by the plaintiff in an unsuccessful attempt to recover the said amount from the said joint wroogdoer), whether by reason of the said’ joint wrongdoer’s insolvency or otherwise, may be recovered by the plaintiff from the other joint wrongdoer, or, if there are two or more ather joint wrongdoers, from those other joint vwrongoers in sach proportions as the court may deem just and equitable having regard to the degree in which each of such other joint wrongdoers was at fault in relation to the damage suffered by the plaintiff;

(iti) may, where it gives judgment against the joint ‘wrongdoers jointly and severally as aforesaid, a tee request of any one of the joint wrongdoers, apportion, for the purposes of paragraph (6), the damages payable by the joint wrongdoers, inéer se, amongst the joint wrongdoars, in such proportions as the court may Seem just and equitable having regard to the egies in which each joint wrongdoer was at fault in relation to the damage suffered by the plaintiff;

{iv) may make such order as to costs as it may ‘coneider just, including an order that the foim wrongdosrs against whom it gives judgment shall py the plaintiff's costs jointly and several iy the one paying and the other being absolved, and that, if one of the ‘onettocessfal joint wrongdoers pays, more than his pro rate share of the plaintifi’s costs, he shall be entitled to recover from each of the other unsuccessful joint wrongdoers his pro rata share of each excess.

(®} Any joint wrongdoer who pays more than the amount apportioned to him under sub-paragraph (iii) of paragraph (2) of this eub-section may recover from any joiit wrongdoer who has not paid the whole or any portion of the amount so apportioned to him, a eontribation of an amount not exceeding so much’ of the amount so apportioned to the laat-mentioned joint wrongdoer as has not been paid by him, or so much of the amount paid by the first-mentioned joint ronadoet as exceeds the amount so apportioned to him. whichever is less.
(2) The provisions of paragraph (0) of sub-section (6) shall apply mutatis mutandis to any claim for a contribution under paragraph () of this sub-section.
(8) Where judgment is given in favour of any joint errongdoer, the court may make such order as € costa as it may consider just, including an order—
{a) that the plaintiff pay such joint wrongdoer’s
costs; or
(®) that the unsuccessful joint wrongdoers pay the

costs of the successful joint wrongdoer jointly and severally, the one paying and the Sther being absolved, and that, if one of the unsuccessful joint wrongdoers pays more than his pro rata share of the costs of the suocessful joint wrongdoer, he shall be entitled to recover from each of the other unsuocessful joint wrongdoers his pro rata share of such excess, and that, if the success- ful joint wrongdoer is unable to recover the whole or any part of his costs from the unsuccessful joint wrongdoers, he shall be entitled to recover from the plaintiff euch part of his costa as he is unable to recover from the unsuccessful joint wrongdoers.

10) Where, by reason of the terms of an agreement belwreen a@ joint wrongioer and the plaintiff, such wrongdoer 1s exempt from liability for the damage suffered by the plaintiff or his liability therefor 1s limited to an agreed amount, then, 80 much of that portion of the damages which, but for the said agreement and the provisions of paragraph () of sub~ section (6) or paragraph (4) of sub-section (7), could have been recovered from stich Prongdoer in terms of sub-section (8) or (7), or could bave been apportioned to him in terms of sub-paragraph (ii) or (iii) of

from any other joint wroagdoer.

(11) (@) Whenever a joint wrongdoer, who is entitled under any provisions of this section to recover a contribution from any other joint wrongdoer, is unable to recover that contribution or say amount thereof from that other joint wrongdoer, whether by reason of the latter’s insolvency or otherwise, be may

‘recover from any other joint wrongdoer such portion of that contribution, or that amount thereof, as the court may deem just and equitable having regard to the degree in which that otter joint wrongdoer was at fault in relation to the damage suffered by the plaintiff and to the fult amount of the said contri- bation or the said amount thereof, as the case may be.

{®) Any costs inourred by a joint wrongdoer in on unsuccessful attempt to recover any contribution from any other joint wrongdoer shall, for the parpose of paragraph (a) of this sub-section, be added to the amount of that contribution,

iat sum of money, or, if the court is satisfied that the full amount of the damage actually suffered by the : plaintiff is less than that sam of money, for such sam of money as the court determines to be equal to the full amount of the damage actually suffered by the plain- tiff, and in the application of the provisions of ‘para- graph () of the said sub-section (0), any reference
erein to the date of the Judgment shall be construed as a reference to the date of the agreement.
(13) Whenever judgment in any action is given against any joint yremggorr for the full amount of

ie damage suffered by the plaintiff, or whenever any joint wrongdoer has agreed to Bay to the plaintiff & soma of money in full settlement of the plaintifi’s claim, and the judgment debt or the said sum of money has been paid in full, every other joint wrongdoer shall thereby also be discharged from any further liability towards the plaintiff.

8 Law Reform (Contributory Negligence and Joint Wrongdoers) Act, No. ‘8 o 1968 (14) A person shall, for the purposes of thi section, be regarded as a joint wrongdoer, notwith- standing the fact that another person had an oppor- tunity of avoiding the, consequences of his wrongful act and negligently failed to do so. Without prejudice to the generality of the Pega © provisions or the application of section 5, the provi- faites sions of that section shall, in particular, apply to any ‘Hvoeed padet liability imposed under Part VI of the Motor Trafic Mor fate Act. on any person in respect of any loss or. damage caused by, oF arising out of, the use or driving of a motor vehicle, 7 PART III GaNERaL Savings. 7. (1) The provisions of this Act shall not—
(a) apply in respect of any wrongful act committed "tore the date of the commencement of this
ct;
(®) operate to defeat any defence arising under a contract;
(©) operate to increase the amount of damages ’ beyond any maximum prescribed in any agreement or any Jaw applicable in respect of any claim for damages.
(2) Nothing in this Act contained shall derogate in

any manner from the provisions of any Jaw relating to collisions or accidents at sea or in the air, an accordingly in the event of any conflict or inconsis- tency between this Act and such provisions, such provisions shall prevail over this Act.
Taterprotation. 8. In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires— j
* court”, in relation to aay claim, means the court or arbitrator by or before whom the claim falls to be determined;
“damage ” includes loss of life and personal =. injury;

“fault? includes any wrongful act, breach of statutory duty or negligent act or omission which gives rise to liability in damages, or would apart from this Act give tise to the defence of contributory negligence.
